column1: Laramie  is a city in and the county seat of Albany County
column3: United States. The population was 30
column4: 816 at the 2010 census. Located on the Laramie River in southeastern Wyoming
column5: the city is north west of Cheyenne
column6: at the junction of Interstate 80 and U.S. Route 287.

column1: Laramie was settled in the mid-19th century along the Union Pacific Railroad line
column2: which crosses the Laramie River at Laramie. It is home to the University of Wyoming
column3: WyoTech
column4: and a branch of Laramie County Community College. Laramie Regional Airport serves Laramie. The ruins of Fort Sanders
column6: lie just south of the city along Route 287. Located in the Laramie Valley between the Snowy Range and the Laramie Range
column7: the city draws outdoor enthusiasts with its abundance of outdoor activities.

column2: Laramie was named as one of the best cities in which to retire by Money Magazine

column1: Laramie was named for Jacques LaRamie
column2: a French or French-Canadian trapper who disappeared in the Laramie Mountains in the early 1820s and was never heard from again. He was one of the first Europeans to visit the area. European-American settlers named a river
column3: mountain range
column4: peak
column6: county
column7: and city for him. More Wyoming landmarks are named for him than for any other trapper but Jim Bridger. Because the name was used so frequently
column8: the town was called Laramie City for decades to distinguish it from other uses.

column1: The city was founded in the mid-1860s as a tent city near the Overland Stage Line route
column2: the Union Pacific portion of the first transcontinental railroad
column3: and just north of Fort Sanders army post. The rails reached Laramie on May 4
column4: 1868 when construction crews worked through town. A few passengers arrived on that same day. The first regular passenger service began on May 10
column6: by which time entrepreneurs were building more permanent structures. Laramie City (as it was known in early years) soon had stores
column7: houses
column8: a school
column9: and churches.   Laramie's fame as the western terminal of the Union Pacific Railroad
column10: acquired when the 268-mile (431 km) section from North Platte
column12: ended in early August 1868 when a 93-mile (150 km) section of track was opened to Benton
column13: 6 miles (9.7 km) east of present-day Sinclair

column1: The frontier town initially suffered from lawlessness. Its first mayor
column3: resigned his office on June 12
column4: 1868 after six turbulent weeks
column5: saying that the other officials elected alongside him on May 2 were guilty of "incapacity and laxity" in dealing with the city's problems.  This was due to the threat to the community from three half-brothers
column6: early Old West gunman "Big" Steve Long
column7: Con Moyer and Ace Moyer. Long was Laramie's first marshal
column8: and with his brothers owned the saloon Bucket of Blood. The three began harassing settlers
column9: forcing them to sign over the deeds to their property to them. Any who refused were killed
column10: usually goaded into a gunfight by Long. By October 1868

column3: organized a "Vigilance Committee" in response. On October 28
column5: Boswell led the committee into the Bucket of Blood
column6: overwhelmed the three brothers
column7: and lynched them at an unfinished cabin down the street. Through a series of other lynchings and other forms of intimidation
column8: the vigilantes reduced the "unruly element" and established a semblance of law and order.

column2: Wyoming was organized as Wyoming Territory
column3: the first legislature of which passed a bill granting equal political rights to women in the territory. In March 1870
column4: five Laramie residents became the first women in the world to serve on a jury. As Laramie was the first town in Wyoming to hold a municipal election
column7: Laramie resident Louisa Swain was the first woman in the United States to cast a legal vote in a general election.Early businesses included rolling mills
column8: a railroad-tie treatment plant
column14: as well as the railroad yards. In 1886
column15: a plant to produce electricity was built.  Several regional railroads were based in Laramie
column17: North Park and Pacific Railroad and Telegraph Company founded in 1880 and the Laramie
column18: North Park and Western Railroad established in 1901.

column1: Governor Francis E. Warren signed a bill that established the University of Wyoming (UW) in 1886
column2: the only public university in the state. Laramie was chosen as its site
column3: and UW opened there in 1887. Under the terms of the Morrill Act
column4: also known as the Land Grant College Act
column5: in 1891 UW added an agricultural college and experiment station to gain benefits as a land grant college.

column1: The city was covered by international media in 1998 after the murder of Matthew Shepard
column2: a gay student at the University of Wyoming. His murder generated an international outcry. It became the symbolic focus for a nationwide campaign against gay hate crimes. Federal hate crimes legislation was signed into law in 2009. As of May 2016
column3: Wyoming does not have a hate crimes law. Shepard's murder was the subject of the award-winning play
column4: later adapted as a movie
column6: Laramie became the first city in Wyoming to pass a law to prohibit smoking in enclosed workplaces
column7: including bars
column8: restaurants and private clubs. Opponents of the clean indoor air ordinance
column9: funded in part by the R.J. Reynolds Tobacco Company
column10: immediately petitioned to have the ordinance repealed. However
column11: the voters upheld the ordinance in a citywide referendum which was conducted concurrently with the 2004 general election. The opponents challenged the validity of the election in court
column13: the judge ruled that the opponents had failed to meet their burden of showing significant problems with the election
column15: which had become effective in April 2005
column17: Laramie's City Council defeated an attempt to amend the ordinance to allow smoking in bars and private clubs.

column1: Laramie's total precipitation averages about 11 inches (279 mm) a year
column2: and the average number of rainy days per year is about 86. The city experiences a day that is 90 °F (32 °C) or warmer 2.2 times a year. The average temperature in December is 21.1 °F (−6.1 °C)
column3: and in July it is 64.0 °F (17.8 °C). Annual snowfall averages 48 inches (122 cm). Because of the high elevation
column4: winters are long
column5: and summers are short and relatively cool. The growing season is short
column6: as the average window for freezing temperatures is September 14 through June 6
column7: while for accumulating (≥0.1 inches or 0.25 centimetres) it is October 5 through May 12.

column1: The University of Wyoming Cowboys compete at the NCAA Division I level (FBS-Football Bowl Subdivision for football) as a member of the Mountain West Conference.  UW offers 17 NCAA-sanctioned sports teams – nine women's sports and eight men's sports. Wyoming's nine NCAA sports for women include basketball; cross country; golf; soccer; swimming and diving; tennis; indoor track & field; outdoor track and field; and volleyball. UW's eight NCAA sports for men include basketball; cross country; football; golf; swimming and diving; indoor track and field; outdoor track and field; and wrestling.

column1: Laramie has a council–manager form of government. The council
column3: consists of nine members who serve overlapping four-year terms. The council members set policy

column6: appoint citizen volunteers to advisory boards
column7: and oversee the city staff. Two members of the council are elected from each of three wards. The council picks a mayor and vice-mayor once every two years at the first council meeting in January. Laramie is the county seat of Albany County and houses county offices
